conversation.speaker: Materials Specialist
conversation.text: We recently switched to using PBT instead of ABS for a housing component. The shrinkage behavior was quite different—had to compensate with a 0.8% dimensional adjustment.

conversation.speaker: Tooling Designer
conversation.text: Interesting. Did you notice any differences in flow behavior? PBT tends to have higher viscosity, especially with 30% glass fill.

conversation.speaker: Process Engineer
conversation.text: Right, and that affects fill pressure. We had to bump up injection pressure by 10% and tweak the V/P switchover point.

conversation.speaker: Quality Control Expert
conversation.text: Did that solve your warpage issues? We usually see warpage around thick-to-thin transitions, especially with semi-crystalline materials like PBT.

conversation.speaker: Materials Specialist
conversation.text: Mostly. But we also redesigned the gate location to avoid jetting and ensure uniform flow front. That helped a lot with part symmetry.

conversation.speaker: Tooling Designer
conversation.text: Gating changes make a huge difference. We’ve been using sequential valve gating for multi-cavity tools. Reduces weld lines significantly.

conversation.speaker: Process Engineer
conversation.text: Also helps with balancing the fill across cavities. We’re using pressure sensors inside the mold now to monitor fill pressure live.

conversation.text: Tool steel choice also matters. We moved to H13 with conformal cooling via DMLS in one of our tools—cycle time dropped by 18%.

conversation.text: Mostly. But we also redesigned the gate location to avoid jetting and ensure uniform flow front. That helped a lot with part symmetry.
